The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.p:
THE formation of a good government, is the greateÅ¿t effort of human wiÅ¿dom, actuated by diÅ¿intereÅ¿ted
patriotiÅ¿m; but Å¿uch is the curÅ¿ed nature of ambition, Å¿o prevalent in the minds of men, that it would Å¿acrifice every thing to its Å¿elfiÅ¿h gratification; hence the faireÅ¿t opportunities of advancing the happineÅ¿s of humanity, are Å¿o far from being properly improved, that they are too often covered with the votaries of power and domination, into the means of obtaining their nefarious ends. It will be the misfortune of America to add to the number of examples of this kind, if the propoÅ¿ed plan of government Å¿hould be adopted; but I truÅ¿t, Å¿hort as the time allowed you for conÅ¿ideration is, you will be Å¿o fully convinced of the truth of this, as to eÅ¿cape the impending danger; it is only neceÅ¿Å¿ary to Å¿trip the monÅ¿ter of its aÅ¿Å¿umed garb, and to exhibit it in its native colours, to excite the univerÅ¿al abhorrence and rejection of every virtuous and patriotic mind.

If you viewed the magnitude of the object in its true light, you would join with me in Å¿entiment, that the new government ought not to be implicitly admitted. ConÅ¿ider then, duly, before you

If you were even well aÅ¿Å¿ured, that the utmoÅ¿t purity of intention predominated in the production of the propoÅ¿ed government, Å¿uch is the imperfection of human wiÅ¿dom and knowledge, that it would not be wiÅ¿e in you to adopt it with precipitation in toto, for all former experience muÅ¿t teach you the propriety of a reviÅ¿ion on Å¿uch occaÅ¿ions, to correct the errors, and Å¿upply the deficiencies that may appear neceÅ¿Å¿ary. What then are we to think of the motives and deÅ¿igns of thoÅ¿e men who are urging the implicit and immediate adoption of the propoÅ¿ed government? Are they fearful, that if you exerciÅ¿e your good Å¿enÅ¿e and diÅ¿cernment, you will diÅ¿cover the maÅ¿qued ariÅ¿tocracy that they are attempting to Å¿muggle upon you, under the Å¿uÅ¿picious garb of republicaniÅ¿m? However, that which could not be accompliÅ¿hed in
the Å¿everal Å¿tates, is now attempting through the medium of the future CongreÅ¿s. The anxiety on this head was greatly increaÅ¿ed, from the impoveriÅ¿hment and diÅ¿treÅ¿s occaÅ¿ioned by the extenÅ¿ive importations of foreign merchandize and luxuries, and conÅ¿equent drain of Å¿pecie Å¿ince the peace: thus the people were in the diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of a drowning man, eager to catch at any thing that promiÅ¿ed relief, however deluÅ¿ory. Such an opportunity for the acquiÅ¿ition of undue power, has never been viewed with indifference by the ambitious and deÅ¿igning in any age or nation, and it has accordingly been too Å¿ucceÅ¿sfully improved by Å¿uch men among us. The deputies from this Å¿tate (with the exception of two) and moÅ¿t of thoÅ¿e from the other Å¿tates in the union were unfortunately of this complexion, and many of them of Å¿uch Å¿uperior endowments, that in an ex parte diÅ¿cuÅ¿Å¿ion of the Å¿ubject, by Å¿pecious gloÅ¿Å¿es, they have gained the concurrence of Å¿ome well-diÅ¿poÅ¿ed men in whom their country have great confidence, which has given great Å¿anction to their Å¿cheme of power.

A compariÅ¿on of the authority under which the convention acted, and their form of government, will Å¿hew that they have deÅ¿piÅ¿ed their delegated power, and aÅ¿Å¿umed Å¿overeignty; that they have entirely annihilated the old confederation, and the particular governments of the Å¿everal Å¿tates, and inÅ¿tead thereof have eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed one general government that is to pervade the union; conÅ¿tituted on the moÅ¿t unequal principle â¢ , deÅ¿titute of accountability to its conÅ¿tituents, and as deÅ¿potic in its nature as the Venetian ariÅ¿tocracy; a government that will give full Å¿cope to the magnificent deÅ¿igns of the well-born; a government where tyranny may glu â¢ its vengeance on the low-born, unchecked by an odious bill of rights, as has been fully illuÅ¿trated in my two preceeding numbers; and yet as a blind upon the underÅ¿tanding of the people, they have continued the forms of the particular governments, and termed the whoÅ¿e a

The convention, after veÅ¿ting all the great and efficient powers of Å¿overeignty in the general government, inÅ¿idiouÅ¿ly declared, by Å¿ection 4th of article 4th, "that the United States Å¿hall guarantee to every Å¿tate in this union, a republican form of government;" but of what avail will be the form without the reality of freedom?

The authors and advocates of the new plan, conÅ¿cious that its eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hment can only be obtained from the ignorance of the people of its true nature, and their unbounded confidence in Å¿ome of the men concurring, have hurried on its adoption with a precipitation that betrays their deÅ¿ign; before many had Å¿een the new plan, and before they had time to examine it, they, by

We Å¿hould, however, be careful in forming our opinions on this Å¿ubject, not to impute the temporary and extraordinary difficulties that have hitherto impeded the execution of the confederation, to defects in the Å¿yÅ¿tem itÅ¿elf. Taxation is, in every government, a very delicate and difficult Å¿ubject; hence it has been the policy of all wiÅ¿e Å¿tateÅ¿men, as far as circumÅ¿tances permitted, to lead the people by Å¿mall beginnings, and almoÅ¿t imperceptible degrees; into the habits of taxation; where the contrary conduct has been purÅ¿ued, it has ever failed of full Å¿ucceÅ¿s, not unfrequently proving the ruin of the projectors. The impoÅ¿ing of a burdenÅ¿ome tax at once on a people, without the uÅ¿ual gradations, is the Å¿evereÅ¿t teÅ¿t that any government can be put to; deÅ¿potiÅ¿m it Å¿elf has often prov â¢ d unequal to the attempt. Under this conviction, let us take a review of our Å¿ituation before and Å¿ince the revolution. Fr â¢ m the firÅ¿t Å¿ettlement of this country, until the commencement of the late war, the taxes were Å¿o light and trivial as to be Å¿carcely felt by the people; when we engaged in the expenÅ¿ive conteÅ¿t with Great Britain, the CongreÅ¿s, Å¿enÅ¿ible of the difficulty of levying the monies neceÅ¿Å¿ary to its Å¿upport, by direct taxation, had recourÅ¿e to an anticipation

Our allies were applied to in this exigence, but the pecuniary aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance that we could procure from them, was Å¿oon exhauÅ¿ted; the only reÅ¿ource now remaining, was to obtain by direct taxation, the monies neceÅ¿Å¿ary for our defence; the hiÅ¿tory of mankind does not furniÅ¿h a Å¿imilar inÅ¿tance of an attempt to levy Å¿uch enormous taxes at once, of a people Å¿o wholly unprepared and u â¢ inured to themâthe lamp of Å¿acred liberty muÅ¿t indeed have burned with unÅ¿ullied luÅ¿tre, every Å¿ordid principle of the mind muÅ¿t have been then extinct, when the people not only Å¿ubmitted to the grievous impoÅ¿itions, but chearfully exerted themÅ¿elves to comply with the calls of their country; their abilities, however, were not equal to furniÅ¿h the neceÅ¿Å¿ary Å¿umsâindeed the requiÅ¿ition of the year 1782, amounted to the whole income of their farms and other property, including the means of their Å¿ubÅ¿iÅ¿tence; perhaps the Å¿trained exertions of two years, would not have Å¿ufficed to the diÅ¿charge of this requiÅ¿ition; to whom then, can we impute the difficulties of the people to a due compliance with the requiÅ¿itions of CongreÅ¿s to a defect in the confederation, for any government, however energetic, in Å¿imilar circumÅ¿tances, would have experienced the Å¿ame fate. If we review the proceedings of the Å¿tates, we Å¿hall find that they gave every Å¿anction and authority to the requiÅ¿itions of CongreÅ¿s, that their

It is a maxim, that a government ought to be cautious not to govern over much, for when the cord of power is drawn too tight, it generally proves its deÅ¿truction; the impracticability of complying with the requiÅ¿itions of CongreÅ¿s has leÅ¿Å¿ened the Å¿enÅ¿e of obligation and duty in the people, and thus weakened the ties of the union; the opinion of power in a free government is much more efficacious than the exerciÅ¿e of it; it requires the maturity of time and repeated practice to give it due energy and certainty to the operations of government, eÅ¿pecially to Å¿uch as affect the purÅ¿es of the people.

The thirteen SwiÅ¿s Cantons confederated by more general and weaker ties than theÅ¿e United States are by the preÅ¿ent articles of confederation, have not experienced the neceÅ¿Å¿ity of Å¿trengthening their union by veÅ¿ting their general diet with further or greater powers; this national body has only the management of their foreign concerns, and in caÅ¿e of a war can onl â¢ call by requiÅ¿ition on the Å¿everal Cantons for the neceÅ¿Å¿ary Å¿upplies, who are Å¿overeign and independent in every internal and local exerciÅ¿e of government; and yet this rope of Å¿and, as our confederation has been termed, which is Å¿o Å¿imilar to that, has held together for ages without any apparent chain.

I am perÅ¿uaded, that a due conÅ¿ideration will evince, that the preÅ¿ent inefficacy of the requiÅ¿itions of CongreÅ¿s is not owing to a defect in the confederation, but the peculiar circumÅ¿tances of the times.

The wheels of the general government having been thus clogged, and the arrearages of taxes Å¿till accumulating, it may be aÅ¿ked what proÅ¿pect is there of the government reÅ¿uming its proper tone, unleÅ¿s more compulÅ¿ory powers are granted? To this it may be anÅ¿wered, that the produce of impoÅ¿ts on commerce which all agree to veÅ¿t in CongreÅ¿s, together with the immenÅ¿e tracts of land at their diÅ¿poÅ¿al, will rapidly leÅ¿Å¿en and eventually diÅ¿charge the preÅ¿ent incumbrances; when

It is to be lamented that the intereÅ¿ted and deÅ¿igning have availed themÅ¿elves Å¿o Å¿ucceÅ¿sfully of the preÅ¿ent criÅ¿is, and under the Å¿pecious pretence of having diÅ¿covered a panacea for all the ills of the people, they are about eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hing a Å¿yÅ¿tem of government that will prove more deÅ¿tructive to them, than the wooden horÅ¿e filled with Å¿oldiers did in ancient times to the city of Troy; this horÅ¿e was introduced by their hoÅ¿tile enemy the Grecians, by a proÅ¿titution of the Å¿acred rites of their religion; in like manner, my fellow citizens, are aÅ¿piring deÅ¿pots among yourÅ¿elves, proÅ¿tituting the name of a WaÅ¿hington to cloak their deÅ¿igns upon your liberties.

I would aÅ¿k how is the propoÅ¿ed government to Å¿how, or down thoÅ¿e treaÅ¿ures upon every claÅ¿s of citizens as is Å¿o induÅ¿triouÅ¿ly inculcated and Å¿o fondly believed?â Is it by the addition of numerous and expenÅ¿ive eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hments? Is it by doubling our judiciaries, inÅ¿tituting federal courts in every county of every Å¿tate? Is it by a Å¿uperb preÅ¿idential court? Is it by a large Å¿tanding army? In Å¿hort, is it by putting it in the power of the future government to levy money at pleaÅ¿ure, and placing this government Å¿o independent of the people as to enable the adminiÅ¿tration to gratify every corrupt paÅ¿Å¿ion of the mind, to riot on your Å¿poils, without check or controul?

A transfer to CongreÅ¿s of the power of impoÅ¿ing impoÅ¿ts on commerce, and the unlimited regulation of trade, I believe is all that is wanting to render America as proÅ¿perous as it is in the power of any form of government to render her; this properly underÅ¿tood would meet the views of all the honeÅ¿t and well meaning.

What gave birth to the Continental Convention?â Was it not the Å¿ituation of our commerce, which lay at the mercy of every foreign power, who from motives of intereÅ¿t or enmity could reÅ¿trict and controul it, without riÅ¿queing a retaliation on the part of America, as CongreÅ¿s
was impotent on this Å¿ubject? Such indeed was the caÅ¿e with reÅ¿pect to Britain, whoÅ¿e hoÅ¿tile regulations gave Å¿uch a Å¿tab to our navigation as to threaten its annihilation, it became the intereÅ¿t of the American merchant to give a preference to foreign bottoms; hence the diÅ¿treÅ¿s of our Å¿eamen, Å¿hip-wrights, and every mechanic art dependent on navigation.

By theÅ¿e regulations too we were limited in markets for our produce, our veÅ¿Å¿els were excluded from their WeÅ¿t-India iÅ¿lands, many of our Å¿taple commodities were denied entrance in Britain; hence the huÅ¿b â¢ ndmen were diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿ed by the demand for their crops being leÅ¿Å¿ened, and their prices reduced. This is the Å¿ource to which may be traced every evil we experience, that can be relieved by a more energetic government. Recollect the language of complaint for years paÅ¿t, compare the recommendations of CongreÅ¿s founded on Å¿uch complaints, pointing out the remedy; examine the reaÅ¿ons aÅ¿Å¿igned by the different Å¿tates for appointing delegates to the late convention, view the powers veÅ¿ted in that body; they all harmonize in one Å¿entiment, that the due regulation of trade and navigation was the anxious wiÅ¿h of every claÅ¿s of citizens, was the great object of calling the convention.

This object being provided for by the propoÅ¿ed conÅ¿titution, the people overlook, and are not Å¿enÅ¿ible of the needleÅ¿s Å¿acrifice they are making for it. Of what avail will be a proÅ¿perous Å¿tate of commerce, when the produce of it will be at the abÅ¿olute diÅ¿poÅ¿al of an arbitrary and unchecked government, who may levy at pleaÅ¿ure the moÅ¿t oppreÅ¿Å¿ive taxes; who may deÅ¿troy every principle of freedom; who may even deÅ¿troy the privilege of complaining.

The evil genius of darkneÅ¿s preÅ¿ided at its birth, it came forth under the veil of myÅ¿tery, its true features being carefully concealed, and every deceptive art has been and is practiÅ¿ing to have this Å¿purious brat received as the genuine offspring of heaven-born liberty. So
fearful are its patrons that you Å¿hould diÅ¿cern the impoÅ¿ition that they have hurried on its adoption with the greateÅ¿t precipitation; they have endeavoured alÅ¿o to preclude all inveÅ¿tigation, they have endeavoured to intimidate all oppoÅ¿ition; by Å¿uch means as the â¢ e have they Å¿urreptitiouÅ¿ly procured a convention in this Å¿t â¢ te, favourable to their views; and here again inveÅ¿tigation and diÅ¿cuÅ¿Å¿ion are abridged, the final queÅ¿tion is moved before the Å¿ubject has been under conÅ¿ideration! An appeal to the people is precluded even in the laÅ¿t reÅ¿ â¢ rt, leÅ¿t their eyes Å¿hould be opened; the convent â¢ on have denied the minority the privilege of entering, the reaÅ¿ons of their diÅ¿Å¿ent on its journals. Thus deÅ¿potiÅ¿m is already triumphant, and the genius of liberty is on the e â¢ e of her exit, is about bidding an eternal adieu to this once happy people.

After Å¿o recent a triumph over BritiÅ¿h deÅ¿pots, after Å¿uch torrents of blood and treaÅ¿ure have been Å¿pent, after involving ourÅ¿elves in the diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿es of an arduous war, and incurring Å¿uch a debt, for the expreÅ¿s purpoÅ¿e of aÅ¿Å¿erting the rights of humanity, it is truly aÅ¿toniÅ¿hing that a Å¿et of men among ourÅ¿elves Å¿hould have the effrontery to attempt the deÅ¿truction of our liberties.â But in this enlightened age to hope to dupe the people by the arts they are practiÅ¿ing, is Å¿till more extraordinary. How do the advocates of the propoÅ¿ed government combat the objections urged againÅ¿t it? Not even by an attempt to diÅ¿prove them, for that would the more fully confirm their truth, but by a Å¿pecies of reaÅ¿oning that is very congenial to that contempt of the underÅ¿tandings of the people that they Å¿o eminently poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿s, and which policy cannot even prevent frequent ebullitions of; they Å¿eem to think that the oratory and faÅ¿cination of great names and mere Å¿ound will Å¿uffice to enÅ¿ure Å¿ucceÅ¿s;â that the people may be diverted from a conÅ¿ideration of the merits of the plan, by bold aÅ¿Å¿ertions and mere declamation. Some of their writers for inÅ¿tance, paint the diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿es of every claÅ¿s of citizens with all the glowing language of eloquence, as if this was a demonÅ¿tration of the excellence, or even of the Å¿afety of the new plan, which notwithÅ¿tanding the reality of this diÅ¿treÅ¿s, may be a Å¿yÅ¿tem of tyranny and oppreÅ¿Å¿ion; other writers
tell you of the great men who compoÅ¿ed the late convention, and give you a pompous diÅ¿play of their virtues, inÅ¿tead of a juÅ¿tification of the plan of government; and others again urge the tyrants plea, they endeavour to make it a caÅ¿e of neceÅ¿Å¿ity, now is the critical moment; they repreÅ¿ent the adoption of this government as our only alternative, as the laÅ¿t opportunity we Å¿hall have of peaceably eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hing a government; they aÅ¿Å¿ert it to be the beÅ¿t Å¿yÅ¿tem that can be formed, and that if we reject it we will have a worÅ¿e one or none at all; nay, that if we preÅ¿ume to propo â¢â¢
â¢ lterations we Å¿hall get into a labyrinth of difficulti â¢â¢
â¢â¢ om which we cannot be extricated, as no two Å¿tate â¢â¢ ll agree in amendments, that therefore it would involve us in irreconcilable diÅ¿cord. But they all Å¿edulouÅ¿ly avoid the fair field of argument, a rational inveÅ¿tigation into the organization of the propoÅ¿ed government. I hope the good Å¿enÅ¿e of the people will detect the fallacy of Å¿uch conduct, will diÅ¿cover the baÅ¿e juggle, and with becoming reÅ¿olution reÅ¿ent the impoÅ¿ition.

That the powers of CongreÅ¿s ought to be Å¿trengthened all allow, but is this a concluÅ¿ive proof of the neceÅ¿Å¿ity to adopt the propoÅ¿ed plan; is it a proof that becauÅ¿e the late convention in the firÅ¿t eÅ¿Å¿ay upon Å¿o arduous and difficult a Å¿ubject, harmonized in their ideas, that a future convention will not, or that after a full inveÅ¿tigation and mature conÅ¿ideration of the objections, they will not plan a better government, and one more agreeable to the Å¿entiments of America; or is it any proof that they can never again agree in any plan? The late convention muÅ¿t indeed have been inÅ¿pired, as Å¿ome of its advocates have aÅ¿Å¿erted, to admit the truth of theÅ¿e poÅ¿itions, or even to admit the poÅ¿Å¿ibility of the propoÅ¿ed government being Å¿uch a one as America ought to adopt; for this body went upon original ground foreign from their intentions or powers, they muÅ¿t therefore have been wholly uninformed of the Å¿entiments of their conÅ¿tituents in reÅ¿pect to this form of government, as it was not in their contemplation when the convention was appointed to erect a new government, but to Å¿trengthen the old one. Indeed they Å¿eem to have been determined to monopolize the excluÅ¿ive merit of the diÅ¿covery,

Is there any reaÅ¿on to preÅ¿ume that a new Convention will not agree upon a better plan of government? div.head: CENTINEL, NUMBER V. To the PEOPLE of PENNSYLVANIA.
div.p:
MR. WILSON, in a Å¿peech delivered in our convention on Saturday the 24th inÅ¿tant, has conceded, nay forceably proved, that one conÅ¿olidated government will not anÅ¿wer for Å¿o extenÅ¿ive a territory as the United States includes, that Å¿lavery would be the
neceÅ¿Å¿ary fate of the people under Å¿uch a government â¢ , his words are Å¿o remarkable, that I cannot forbear reciting them; they are as follows, viz. "The extent of country for which the new conÅ¿titution was required, produced another difficulty in the buÅ¿ineÅ¿s of the federal convention. It is the opinion of Å¿ome celebrated writers, that to a Å¿mall territory, the democratical, to a middling territory, as MonteÅ¿quien has termed it, the monarchical, and, to an extenÅ¿ive territory, the deÅ¿potic form of government is the beÅ¿t adapted. For, we knew, that although our conÅ¿tituents would chearfu â¢ ly Å¿ubmit to the legiÅ¿lative reÅ¿traints of a free government, they would Å¿purn at every attempt to Å¿hackle them with deÅ¿potic power." See page five of the printed Å¿peech. And again in page Å¿even, he Å¿ays, "Is it probable, that the diÅ¿Å¿olution of the Å¿tate governments, and the eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hment of one conÅ¿olidated empire, would be eligible in its nature, and Å¿atisfactory to the people in its adminiÅ¿tration? I think not, as I have given reaÅ¿ons to Å¿hew, that Å¿o extenÅ¿ive a territory could not be governed, connected, and preÅ¿erved, but by the Å¿upremacy of deÅ¿potic power. All the exertions of the moÅ¿t potent emperors of Rome, were not capable of keeping that empire together, which, in extent, was far inferior to the dominion of America."

This great point having been now confirmed by the conceÅ¿Å¿ion of Mr WilÅ¿on, though indeed it was Å¿elf evident before, and the writers againÅ¿t the propoÅ¿ed plan of government, having proved to demonÅ¿tration, that the powers propoÅ¿ed to be veÅ¿ted in CongreÅ¿s, will neceÅ¿Å¿arily annihilate and abÅ¿orb the legiÅ¿latures and judiciaries, and produce from their wreck one conÅ¿olidated government, the queÅ¿tion is determined. Every man therefore who has the welfare of his country at heart, every man who values his own liberty and happineÅ¿s, in Å¿hort, every deÅ¿cription of perÅ¿ons, except thoÅ¿e aÅ¿piring deÅ¿pots who hope to benefit by the miÅ¿ery and vaÅ¿Å¿alage of their countrymen, muÅ¿t now concur in
rejecting the propoÅ¿ed Å¿yÅ¿tem of government, muÅ¿t now unite in branding its authors with the Å¿tigma of eternal infamy. The anniverÅ¿ary of this great eÅ¿cape from the fangs of deÅ¿potiÅ¿m, ought to be celebrated as long as liberty Å¿hall continue to be dear to the citizens of America.
I will repeat Å¿ome of my principal arguments, and add Å¿ome further remarks, on the Å¿ubject of conÅ¿olidation.

The legiÅ¿lative is the higheÅ¿t delegated power in government; all other are Å¿ubordinate to it. The celebrated MonteÅ¿quie â¢
â¢â¢ tabliÅ¿hes it as a maxim, that legiÅ¿lation neceÅ¿Å¿arily follows the power of taxation. By the 8th â¢ ection of article the firÅ¿t of the propoÅ¿ed governm â¢â¢ t, "the CongreÅ¿s are to have power to lay and collect taxes, duties, impoÅ¿ts, and exciÅ¿es, to pay the debts, and provide for the common defence and general welfare of the United States." Now, what can be more comprehenÅ¿ive than theÅ¿e words? Every Å¿pecies of taxation, whether external or internal, are included. Whatever taxes, duties, â¢â¢ d exciÅ¿es, that the CongreÅ¿s may deem neceÅ¿Å¿ary to the general welfare, may be impoÅ¿ed on the citizens of theÅ¿e Å¿tates and levied by their officers. The CongreÅ¿s are to be the abÅ¿olute judges of the propriety of Å¿uch taxes, in Å¿hort they may conÅ¿true every purpoÅ¿e for which the Å¿tate legiÅ¿latures now lay taxes, to be for the general welfare, they may Å¿eize upon every Å¿ource of taxation, and thus make it impracticable for the Å¿tates to have the Å¿malleÅ¿t revenue; and if a Å¿tate Å¿ â¢â¢â¢ ld preÅ¿ume to impoÅ¿e a tax or exciÅ¿e, that would interfere with the federal tax or exciÅ¿e, CongreÅ¿s may Å¿oon terminate the contention, by repealing the Å¿tate law, by virtue of the following Å¿ection; "To make all laws which Å¿hall be neceÅ¿Å¿ary and proper for carrying into execution the foregoing powers, and all other powers veÅ¿ted by this conÅ¿titution in the government of the United States, or in any department thereof." Indeed every law of the Å¿tates may be controuled by this power. The legiÅ¿lative power granted by theÅ¿e Å¿ections, is Å¿o unlimited in its nature, may be Å¿o comprehenÅ¿ive and boundleÅ¿s in its exerciÅ¿e, that this alone would be amply Å¿ufficient to carry the co â¢ p d â¢ grace to the Å¿tate governments,
to Å¿wallow them up in the grand vortex of general empire. But the legiÅ¿lative has an able auxiliary in the judicial department, for a reference to my Å¿econd number will Å¿hew, that this may be made greatly inÅ¿trumental in effecting a conÅ¿olidation; as the federal judiciary would abÅ¿orb all others. LeÅ¿t the foregoing powers Å¿hould not Å¿uffice to conÅ¿olidate the United States into one empire, the convention, as if determined to prevent the poÅ¿Å¿ibility of a doubt, as if to prevent all claÅ¿hing by the oppoÅ¿ition of Å¿tate powers, as if to preclude all Å¿truggle for Å¿tate importance, as if to level all obÅ¿tacles to the Å¿upremacy of univerÅ¿al Å¿way, which in Å¿o extenÅ¿ive a territory would be an iron handed deÅ¿potiÅ¿m, have ordained by article the 6th, "That this conÅ¿titution, and the laws of the United States, which Å¿hall be made in purÅ¿uance thereof, and all treaties made, or which Å¿hall be made, under the authority of the United States, Å¿hall be the Å¿upreme law of the land; and the judges in every Å¿tate Å¿hall be bound thereby, any thing in the conÅ¿titution or laws of any Å¿tate to the contrary notwithÅ¿tanding."

The words, "purÅ¿uant to the conÅ¿titution," will be no reÅ¿triction to the authority of CongreÅ¿s; for the foregoing Å¿ections give them unlimited legiÅ¿lation; their unbounded power of taxation does alone include all others, as whoever has the purÅ¿e Å¿trings will have full dominion. But the convention has Å¿uperadded another power, by which the CongreÅ¿s may Å¿tamp with the Å¿anction of the conÅ¿titution every poÅ¿Å¿ible law; it is contained in the following clauÅ¿e: "To make all laws which Å¿hall be neceÅ¿Å¿ary and proper for carrying into execution the foregoing powers, and all other powers veÅ¿ted by this conÅ¿titution in the government of the United States, or in any department or officer thereof." Whatever law CongreÅ¿s may deem neceÅ¿Å¿ary and proper for carrying into execution any of the powers veÅ¿ted in them, may be enacted; and by virtue of this clauÅ¿e, they may controul and abrogate any and every of the laws of the Å¿tate governments, on the allegation that they interfere with the execution of any of their powers; and yet theÅ¿e laws will "be made in purÅ¿uance of the conÅ¿titution," and of courÅ¿e will "be the Å¿upreme law of the
land, and the judges in every Å¿tate Å¿hall be bound thereby, any thing in the conÅ¿titution or laws of any Å¿tate, to the contrary notwithÅ¿tanding.

There is no reÅ¿ervation made in the whole of this plan in favour of the rights of the Å¿eparate Å¿tates. In the preÅ¿ent plan of confederation made in the year 1778, it was thought neceÅ¿Å¿ary by article the 2d to declare, that each Å¿tate retains its Å¿overeignty, freedom, and independence, and every power, juriÅ¿diction, and right, which is not by this confederation expreÅ¿sly delegated to the United States in CongreÅ¿s aÅ¿Å¿embled. PoÅ¿itive grant was not thought Å¿ufficiently deÅ¿criptive and reÅ¿trictive upon CongreÅ¿s, and the omiÅ¿Å¿ion of Å¿uch a declaration now, when Å¿uch great devolutions of power are propoÅ¿ed, manifeÅ¿ts the deÅ¿ign of conÅ¿olidating the Å¿tates.

What reÅ¿triction does Mr. WilÅ¿on pretend there is in the new conÅ¿titution to the Å¿upremacy of deÅ¿potic Å¿way over the United States? What barrier does he aÅ¿Å¿ign for the Å¿ecurity of the Å¿tate governments? Why truly a mere cobweb of a limit! By interpoÅ¿ing the Å¿hield of what will become mere form, to check the reality of power. He Å¿ays, that the exiÅ¿tence of the Å¿tate governments are eÅ¿Å¿ential to the organization of CongreÅ¿s, that the former is made the neceÅ¿Å¿ary baÅ¿is of the latter, for the federal Å¿enators and preÅ¿ident are to be appointed by the Å¿tate legiÅ¿latures; and that hence all fears of a conÅ¿olidation are groundleÅ¿s and imaginary. It muÅ¿t be confeÅ¿Å¿ed, as reaÅ¿on and argument would have been foreign to the defence of the propoÅ¿ed plan of government, Mr. WilÅ¿on has diÅ¿played much ingenuity on this occaÅ¿ion; he has involved the Å¿ubject in all the mazes of Å¿ophiÅ¿try, and by Å¿ubtil diÅ¿tinctions he has eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed principles and poÅ¿itions, that exiÅ¿t only in his own fertile imagination. It is a Å¿oleciÅ¿m in politics for two co-ordinate Å¿overeignties to exiÅ¿t together; you muÅ¿t Å¿eparate the Å¿phere of their juriÅ¿diction, or after running the race of dominion for Å¿ome time, one would neceÅ¿Å¿arily triumph over the other; but in the mean time the Å¿ubjects of it would be harraÅ¿Å¿ed with double impoÅ¿itions to Å¿upport the contention; however, the Å¿trife between CongreÅ¿s and the Å¿tates could not be of long continuance, for the former has a deciÅ¿ive Å¿uperiority in the outÅ¿et, and has
